item.title: The Lede: Assange’s Father Met Assad in Damascus
item.description: Julian Assange’s father met with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria during a visit to Damascus as a member of “a solidarity delegation” from Australia hoping to foster “peace and transparency.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: India’s Biggest Stories in 2013
item.description: A photo journey through the events that made headlines in the country this year.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Rebel Forces Attack Key City in South Sudan
item.description: Rebels and the military engaged in fierce fighting in a city seen as a gateway to the capital, but there were signs that peace talks could soon be held.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: South Sudanese soldiers with a truck-mounted machine gun on Monday in Malakal, some 300 miles northeast of the capital Juba.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Orders Officials to Stop Smoking in Public
item.description: Smoking is one of China’s most serious public health problems, and critics ask if the latest move to curb tobacco use will be any more effective than previous efforts.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI
item.media:description: Delegates to a meeting at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing break for cigarettes.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Women ‘Name and Shame’ Companies They Say Discriminate
item.description: By lodging formal complaints with local government alleging gender-based discrimination in how many Chinese companies hire, a group of women is drawing attention to a well-known problem largely hidden from public debate.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: An activist in Yunnan Province prepares to mail letters to her local government complaining of illegal gender discrimination by Chinese companies.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Divining China’s Direction by What Xi Ate
item.description: The Chinese public is digging deep for portents of the Communist Party’s anticorruption campaign in President Xi Jinping’s recent lunch at a popular steamed bun restaurant in western Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI
item.media:description: Tourists order dishes similar to the ones President Xi Jinping ate at the Qingfeng steamed bun restaurant in Beijing.

item.title: Bomb Attacks in Russia Echo Threats by Chechen Insurgent
item.description: Two terrorist attacks in Volgograd that killed 34 people have sowed fear across the country, and the attention of Russian security services has turned to the insurgent leader Doku Umarov.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: A bomb on a bus in Volgograd, Russia, on Monday killed at least 15 people. It was the second fatal blast in the city in two days.

item.title: Bomb Attacks in Russia Echo Threats by Chechen Insurgent
item.description: Two terrorist attacks in Volgograd have sowed widespread fear across the country, and the attention of Russian security services has turned to the insurgent leader, Doku Umarov.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: A bomb on a bus in Volgograd, Russia, on Monday killed at least 15 people. It was the second fatal blast in the city in two days.

item.title: Baalbek Journal: Beyond Camps, Aiding Syrians Is Even Harder
item.description: Aid groups have strained to help the more than 1.8 million registered Syrian refugees dispersed in Lebanon, Jordan, Turkey and elsewhere, who are harder to reach than those in camps.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Selwa Sairafy, a Syrian, lives with four children and her husband in a schoolroom in Naameh, Lebanon. The school has been overtaken by refugees.

item.title: Lebanon, Worried About Border, Fires on Syrian Helicopters in Its Airspace
item.description: The army’s move was the first such action since a threat last summer to attack troops, vehicles or warplanes entering its territory from Syria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Australia Plans Evacuation of Passengers Stranded in Ice
item.description: Passengers and some crew members aboard a research ship that has been stuck in thick Antarctic ice for nearly a week will be evacuated by helicopter.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN
item.media:credit: Andrew Peacock, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An image from one of the passengers of the Akademik Shokalskiy shows the Russian research ship icebound off Antarctica.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Five Political Prisoners Freed After Pardon
item.description: President Thein Sein on Monday granted a pardon to people convicted of or charged with a variety of political offenses.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Quelling Attacks in the Capital, Congolese Troops Kill Dozens
item.description: Congolese troops responded forcefully to raids on several sites in Kinshasa, apparently by supporters of a disgruntled Christian leader.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Swiss Give Visa to Freed Russian Oil Tycoon
item.description: Switzerland granted Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky a three-month visa entitling him to visit the country where his wife has reportedly lived while he was in prison.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Visa Granted to Pardoned Russian Tycoon
item.description: Switzerland has granted a three-month visa to the former Russian oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, entitling him to visit the country where his wife has reportedly lived.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Gunmen Kill 12 in Attacks in the Northeast
item.description: Gunmen attacked two Christian villages in the mainly Muslim region of northeastern Nigeria over the weekend and killed at least 12 people, witnesses said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Police Kill 8 Assailants in a Clash in Xinjiang
item.description: Violence between civilians and security forces has become increasingly common in Xinjiang, where officials say they are trying to deal with rebels or terrorists.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,286 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Clothing Brands Sidestep Blame for Safety Lapses
item.description: Months after the collapse of the Rana Plaza complex in Bangladesh exposed abuses in the garment industry, there is no consensus on what responsibility global chains should bear for reform and compensation.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fashion designer at an office of Mango in Barcelona, where the workplace is in contrast to factories in places like Bangladesh.

item.title: Russian Tycoon Is Free, but His Money Is Still Tied Up
item.description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky was worth an estimated $15 billion when he went to prison 10 years ago. Now, he can only guess at how much of it is left.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: The Yuganskneftegaz oil processing facility, once the core of the oil company Yukos. Mikhail Khodorkovsky still holds shares.

item.title: New York City’s Office for Immigrants Has Become a Global Model
item.description: During Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s tenure, cities across the country and abroad have looked to the Office of Immigrant Affairs as a resource.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: Fatima A. Shama, New York City's commissioner of immigrant affairs.

item.title: The Lede: Egypt Arrests 4 Al Jazeera English Journalists
item.description: The authorities accused them of broadcasting “false news” that damaged national security and possessing written materials that promoted “incitement,” including information about protests supporting the Muslim Brotherhood.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: Singapore Leads Pack as Cities Prepare for an Influx of Fliers
item.description: Singapore is unusually forward-looking in its expansion, but passenger demand is forcing airports from Beijing to Seoul to grow.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
item.media:credit: Juliana Tan for The New York Times
item.media:description: A swimming pool is one of many amenities at Changi International Airport in Singapore, which also has free movies.

item.title: Spain Tightens Rules for Bottled Olive Oil
item.description: The rules are aimed at improving food hygiene, by banning refillable bottles at restaurants, but oil producers also hope to build stronger brand recognition.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Laura Leon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A farm worker with a machine that shakes the branches of olives trees in Seville, Spain, to make the olives fall to the ground.

item.title: Delayed Plans Muddy Fate of Italian Bank
item.description: The decision comes after a shareholder move to delay selling 3 billion euros in shares needed to raise cash for the bank, Monte dei Paschi di Siena.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI and JACK EWING
